We propose a solution to address the classification and semantic segmentation challenge in a limited labeled dataset. Our approach involves generating pseudo labels for both classification and segmentation during training and gradually increasing the impact of pseudo label loss on the final loss. This semi-supervised method of training significantly improved our baseline supervised loss for classification, enabling the model to generalize and perform better on the validation and test splits of the dataset.

In this paper, we compare and contrast various methods and models for image classification and semantic segmentation on the FloodNet dataset.

Introduction
------------

Natural disasters pose a significant threat to human health, infrastructure, and natural systems. It is crucial to have accurate, timely, and understandable information to improve disaster management systems. High-resolution images from small unmanned aerial systems can be used to collect data from remote areas. Understanding these images is vital for quick response and large-scale recovery post-natural disaster. Classification and segmentation tasks are essential in such situations as they provide scene information to help the task force make decisions.

One of the major challenges in generating a vision dataset is the cost of labeling the data, especially for semantic segmentation. This often leads to labels for only a small percentage of the data, necessitating semi-supervised methods that can produce results comparable to supervised methods. Another challenge is the heavy class imbalance. The lack of labeled data coupled with class imbalance makes it a challenging task to solve.

Our contribution in this paper is two-fold: semi-supervised classification and semi-supervised semantic segmentation. Through our approach, we aim to tackle these problems and produce credible results.

Related Works
-------------

Supervised Classification: Over the years, several architectures and methods have emerged that have leveraged extensive datasets like ImageNet to produce state-of-the-art results using supervised learning. The architectures used in our paper are ResNet and EfficientNet. ResNet proposes a residual connection architecture that makes it feasible to train networks with a large number of layers without escalating the training error percentage. EfficientNet proposes a simple but effective scaling method that can be used to scale up any model architecture to any target resource constraints while maintaining model efficiency.

Supervised Semantic Segmentation: Segmentation aids in extracting the maximum amount of information from an image. Semantic segmentation associates every pixel of an image with a class label. Deep learning models like UNet, PSPNet, and DeepLabV3+ have provided exceptional results for this task. The architecture of UNet is divided into two parts: a contracting path and an expansive path. The contracting path follows the generic framework of a convolutional network, while the expansive path undergoes deconvolution to reconstruct the segmented image.

Semi-supervised Approach: Pseudo-Label proposes a simple semi-supervised learning approach. The idea is to train the neural network in a supervised fashion with both labeled and unlabeled data simultaneously. For unlabeled data, pseudo labels are generated by selecting the class with the maximum predicted probability. This is equivalent to Entropy Regularization, which favors a low-density separation between classes, a commonly assumed prior for semi-supervised learning.

Classification
------------

The dataset consists of 2343 images of dimensions 3000x4000x3, divided into train (1445), valid (450), and test (448) splits. Out of the 1445 train images, 398 are labeled and 1047 are unlabeled. In this section, we describe our approach for classifying the FloodNet dataset.
